title: The True Victim of the League of Legends Ret-Gone.
body:
**Disclaimer:** Not a native or particularly proficient English writer. Unusual or inadequate language constructions might appear.
 
Although I believe that doing away with the League of Legends as a narrative artifact was the right choice (seeing it gone was my secret dream, for reasons very similar to those expressed by Narrative), there is an issue with it that needs to be addressed.
 
In the previous version of Runeterra existed champions like {{champion:9}} Fiddlesticks, {{champion:56}} Nocturne and {{champion:31}} Cho'gath, whose hat was basically 'scary thing being trapped by the Institute of War' (there were variations among them, of course, but functionally that's where they stood), which I think can be executed in a far more satisfying manner if released into the world (figuratively or literally).
 
However, there is a champion that, with the removal of the League of Legends (a massively influential, world-class combat arena), has been left without a clear place in the world, with a vital part of his identity irrevocably seized away from him.
 
I am not talking about {{champion:24}} Jax this time (but a point about him in a moment).
 
I am talking about this guy:
 
http://i.imgur.com/z8Qjt8i.jpg
 
{{champion:119}} Draven's identity revolves primarily around him snatching the biggest spotlight available and pointing it at his glorious mustache. He is the ultimate attention seeker and glory-hound of the game, his backstory repeatingly illustrating his quest for fame and acclamation (up to and including his actual in-game League of Draven passive).
 
Draven’s thirst for acclaim was the sole reason he joined the League (well, that and his lofty desire to gift Draven to a global audience, of course), and the most important part of his character. The League of Legends provided him with a world-class stage from which his renown, his legend, was able to reach basically every person in Runeterra; With the removal of League, that stage is gone, and nothing even remotely comparable remains for the Glorious Executioner to stand on.
 
I first thought about this when pondering how the removal of the League affected Jax. I realized that even though Jax’s lore revolved heavily around the League (the most successful League participant in history), his core as a character (unbeatable master-at-arms) and his motivations (desire to fight strong opponents, presumably) weren’t irrevocably entrenched on the League of Legends. Draven is the opposite case, I believe: His backstory touches only briefly on his enrollment to the League, yet his character (shameless self-promoter and fame-seeker) and motivation (gifting Draven to the world, collecting the adoration that is due to Draven) draws heavily upon the existence of the League of Legends to work to the extent it does.
 
Expanding upon this, my opinion is that while Jax has lost the framework by which his character was showcased, there are other avenues to deliver on his fantasy. Certainly, with the League gone, the Grandmaster-at-Arms can no longer face, fight and humiliatingly defeat combat powerhouses from a dozen of nations on a daily basis, and the loss of his main story blurb is a small tragedy for the lore fandom; However, being that Jax’s identity consist mainly on extreme fighting prowess, there are other ways to make him a part of the world while preserving his original character, and probably most of his (implicit) influence over Runeterra.
 
On the other hand, Draven’s story not only depended upon the previous structure, but was driven by it; He joined the League with the explicit goal of increasing his own reputation and self-exposure. Unlike with Jax, I have not yet seen a way to preserve Draven’s previous presence and influence on the new Runeterra , and I seriously doubt that is possible at all (hopefully I am wrong). Why I believe that? Because that part of Draven’s identity hinges upon a lot of the elements that made the League undesirable to the Narrative team in the first place: A world-spanning, monolithic organization, its influence dictating the politics of Runeterra and permeating all levels of society, with the eyes of the world constantly upon it. Virtually any other forum Draven may get, in Noxus or any other place will probably fall short of the formidable League of Legends, which was home of the finest, most puissant  and most famous (or infamous) heroes of the land. In short, I really think that Draven’s identity will be irrevocably lost, or at least dramatically reduced in scope and magnitude.
 
Now, I don’t believe that preserving a cool character (Draven in this case), or even a dozen of them, was enough reason to prevent the retcon of Runeterra, but still would be a shame if Draven were to lose his identity or place in the world.

Heck, within one CITY (like New York) you have a LOT of different accents from them boys from BROOKLYN to them guys from "Lawn guyland" as they say. It is possible that Demacia has many immigrants, and possibly subregional accents.

Or take England. **Just England**, not Great Britain. England is an island, and it's not even that big compared to many American "states". It's much smaller than **California **where Riot Games is based.

http://i.imgur.com/TDTF0jp.png

Now the above shows Great Britain vs the United States, but take a closer look, and see just how small **England **is. Ignore Ireland and the Isle of Man, cut off Scotland and Wales.

http://i.imgur.com/vYxwYBl.jpg

How many accents could there be in _England_?

Cornish, West Country (stereotypical pirate accent), Geordie, Yorkshire, Lacanshire, Scouse,  East Hertfordshire (East Herts), West Herts, Hampshire, Kent, Norfolk, and more. 

#And LONDON?

Just in the city of London you have Cockney, Estuary English, Multiculural London English, and "Recieved" Pronunciation (most stereotypical British accent, actually spoken by very few people). The following video gives you a little audio tour of accents in **just **_1 minute and a half._

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8mzWkuOxz8

If you have time for a longer watch, about 5 minutes or so, you can hear nearly 25 accents located JUST within England.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2pZ-Ny8q22o

With that said, it seems reasonable to believe that a fantasy state like "Demacia" would have different accents, not just among it's boroughs/districts/etc but also between upper and lower classes in each, and even among subcultures (take Chav English for example) I mean, you dont expect {{champion:59}} to speak like a commoner do you? 

Now, it's true...with a fantasy universe you can create a unique fantasy accent (take Hunger Games' original "Capitol Accent" for example) But....it's easier to just use **REAL **ones from life. Accents have certain qualities associated with them as the video discusses a little (i.e. drunk sounding Welshmen) . They chose "French" for Fiora because it fits the ideas behind the character (and mind you, it's just ONE french accent). 

Now despite this, France does not exist within Runeterra. 

What I'd like to know, is WHERE accents map regionally in Runeterra. Essentially, what part of Demacia is Fiora and the Laurent family from? Is the accent more common than we think -or if not, then where did the Laurents immigrate from? Are there many of them in Demacia, or elsewhere? Was it a kingdom or nation that was unified with others at Demacia's founding, or was it...conquered? In that sense, you shouldnt be suprised characters from the same state can have many different manners of speech, but...what you should be asking is where in Runeterra these accents originate.

Now an important thing to note is that theoretically...."English" does not exist within Runeterra either, despite being spoken by nearly all of it's characters (except {{champion:432}} {{champion:150}} {{champion:421}} ), because there is no "England". 

There's several ways to handle this. There could be a common "trade tongue"/lingua franca that's spoken by all or most characters when not speaking their own native language  -which explains accented English spoken by {{champion:11}} , {{champion:43}} , {{champion:201}} , {{champion:114}} , and others. In this sense, English does not exist, and is merely a stand in. So when we have a character that speaks with say, a rural accent -the character actually speaks a fictional language unknown to us, _but_ the accent in a language the player understands, can convey the characters upbringing. or lifestyle.

#OH AND ONE MORE THING.

When they dub the game into other languages? They have to _redo all the accents._ And they dont use the same ones, but ones speakers of those languages are accustomed to hearing. 

That _aside_ NORTH America _is_ a continent, it has several nation "states" within it -Canada, the United States of America, and Mexico. Within any one of them, you have MANY accents. But I think you know that now.

You know the funny thing is... well I can agree on people portraying Noxus in a better light. But... Demacia? I feel that in conjecture of that people started to enjoy portraying Demacia into a rather dark light (AKA being liars about their creed of justice when they do things as 'bad' as Noxus). Y'know, part of me believes that, for instance, even if Jarvan is a little too bloodthirsty and too eager for battle, there's a part of him that genuinely wants to protect the people of Demacia, and values his companionship with other people, he's surrounded with the likes of Quinn, Shyvana, Xin Zhao, Garen, Lux, as far as military goes. And to note, I think normal Demacian nobility snobs would look down commoners like Quinn or get freaked out on Shyvana being a half-dragon (and probably even worse, ostracize him), but Jarvan still took them in and treat them like equals, in spite of him being the prince.

Or heck, the infamous one, Lux, thanks to her old Judgment. Sure, she has nothing else and felt empty from the inside, but who's to say that her patriotism and dedication to her country are also genuinely part of her good nature that doesn't like the suffering of people and wanting to protect them as much as everyone else?

I know that there's no "bad guy" state, and I might be paranoid, but I feel that in process of whitewashing the 'looking stereotypical bad' guy, we end up painting the 'looking stereotypical good' guy black a bit too much.

So that's about it, do you think there is a part of Demacia that certainly wants to do good?

I don't think we are painting Demacia as black as you've said. We are pulling Noxus and Demacia closer to the grey scale instead of black and white or reversing the scale. Are there part of Demacia that wants to do good? Absolutely, hell, might even be the majority. But what people are doing is not painting Demacia black, we pull it down from it pedestal and examine it fully, acknowledging its deep flaws as well as its merit, the same that we did to Noxus, pull the red and omnious lighting from it and examine it fully, acknowledging its merit as well as its flaw. Both side are very much grey, they are "states", not "bad guy states" and "good guy state"
EDIT: Demacia are not so much liars in their creed of justice, but they are **VERY** self-righteous about it and will go to great length to enforce its morality

It's good that we might be pulling them down from their pedestal. But from what I kinda saw in other discussions, especially those who are... shall we say, less thorough than this, just basically going with one sentence and such (and believe me, there's more of them than thorough discussers like us), it feels that people tends to get invested in pulling Demacia down the pedestal and forgot to acknowledge its good merits. Look at how people viewed Lux's Judgment. They forgot that the conscription also part of defending one's country and people, instead, people say it's a completely black mark in Demacia and makes them eviler than Noxus. I'm very sure you have a way to explain why it's not a completely black act, but... yeah, as you can see.

Self-righteousness is also a topic that is often viewed as an act that propagates hypocrisy, and hypocrites are amongst the most hated kind by the fans. Many often views the "At least I'm honest about it" to be a virtue, which Noxus obviously had, so by the views of many, Demacia being very self-righteous on law is considered something worse than Noxus' murderous freedom (and we also hear cases or stories that makes law bad and undesirable). So all in all, if we're just using the normal cliche, it could be easy to really pull down Demacia from the pedestal way too hard and then we end up painting them black instead of making it 'grey'.

Just my two cents, I could be either wrong or just looking at a dim view based on some select, unintelligent posts.
